arguments.court_reasoning: Not feasible to encase discretion in inflexible formula; quantity of relief unchanged

arguments.claim: Appellate courts have power to allow amendment even post-limitation if required in interests of justice; cites Leach v Jardine Skinner
Power to amend exists even if new claim barred by limitation if special circumstances outweigh; cites Charan Das v Amir Khan
arguments.qualifiers: as a rule... yet there were cases where such considerations were outweighed by the special circumstances

arguments.claim: Amendment akin to Privy Council case under Specific Relief Act s42; defect in plaint curable without changing relief nature
Batchelor test: amendments allowed if no injustice to other side and necessary for real questions in controversy; compensable by costs

holdings.text: Even though the appellate Court had such power or jurisdiction to allow the amendment, that power was properly exercised in the circumstances of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that learned counsel for the appellant did not argue that the appellate Court had no jurisdiction or power to allow the amendment. His submission was that even though the appellate Court had such power or jurisdiction, that power should not have been exercised in the circumstances of the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant conceded power exists; court reviews exercise of discretion considering limitation and delay but finds proper per precedents.

holdings.text: The period of limitation having expired does not affect the power of the court to allow amendment if required in interests of justice; it is only a factor in discretion.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quoting and applying own recent decision in L.J. Leach & Co. v. Jardine Skinner & Co.

holdings.text: Though power to amend should not as a rule deprive defendant of limitation defence, special circumstances can outweigh such considerations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepting Privy Council precedent in Charan Das v. Amir Khan; discretion not exercised on wrong principle here.

holdings.text: The discretion of the High Court was not exercised on a wrong principle.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts similar to Privy Council case; pleader's mistake; no change in relief nature; compensable by costs.

holdings.text: It is neither feasible nor advisable to encase discretionary power to amend within inflexible formula like Beaman test; quantity of relief unaffected here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing Beaman J.'s tests as too rigid; amendment cured pleading defect without changing relief quantum.

holdings.text: Correct principles for amendment are those of Batchelor J.: allow if no injustice to other side (compensable by costs) and necessary for real controversy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Preferring Batchelor over Beaman; ultimate test is absence of injustice; applies to barred claims if no compensable injury.

holdings.text: The same principles [Batchelor] should apply in the present case; amendments do not introduce new case or cause surprise.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendments supply title particulars needed under O. XXI r.103 without new relief or prejudice beyond costs.

precedents.citation: L. J. Leach Co. v. Jardine Skinner Co.  1

anchor.surface_text: L. J. Leach Co. v. Jardine Skinner Co.  1  where, in allowing an amendment of the plaint in an appeal before us, we said It is numberdoubt true that companyrts would, as a rule, decline to allow amendments, if a fresh suit on the amended claim would be barred by limitation on the date of the application. But that is a factor to be taken into account in exercise of the discretion as to whether amendment should be ordered, and does number affect the power of the companyrt to order it, if that is required in the interests of justice.

precedents.case_name: L.J. Leach & Co. v. Jardine Skinner & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: The bar of limitation for a fresh suit on amended claim is a factor for discretion but does not affect the power to allow amendment if required in interests of justice

anchor.surface_text: Charan Das v.
